message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The virus being studied in this scenario replicates itself in the host cell using host ribosomes to translate viral proteins, which are then cleaved by viral proteases. Only Coxsackievirus meets these characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus is a positive-strand RNA virus that can replicate in the cytoplasm of host cells and translate viral proteins using host cell ribosomes. The viral proteins are then cleaved by viral proteases to generate mature viral particles, and the virus's genetic material is replicated using a protein translated from the viral genome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus is known to replicate in the cytoplasm of host cells, using the host's ribosomes to make viral proteins. The virus also has viral proteases that cleave the polyprotein into mature proteins and replicates its RNA using a protein translated from its RNA genome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus has a replication process that matches the description provided in the question. The virus uses host ribosomes to produce large polypeptides that are later cleaved into smaller peptides by viral proteases, and then the virion's genetic material is replicated. Other viruses have different replication processes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus uses the host's ribosomes for protein synthesis and has its proteins cleaved by viral proteases to generate mature viral proteins. The other options have different methods of replication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus has the ability to replicate using host cell ribosomes and proteases to generate mature viral proteins. Measles virus and Parvovirus use viral mRNA to generate viral proteins, while Molluscum contagiosum virus replicates in the cytoplasm using its own machinery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus replicates in this manner. Parvovirus, Measles virus, and Molluscum contagiosum virus all replicate using host cell DNA polymerase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus is known for replicating in the cytoplasm of host cells after infection, and it uses the host cell's ribosomes for protein synthesis. The other viruses replicate in the host cell nucleus or use their own special mechanisms for protein synthesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus is known to replicate in the cytoplasm (since denucleated fibroblasts have no nucleus) and has a protease for cleaving large polypeptides into smaller peptides. Parvovirus, Molluscum contagiosum virus, and Measles virus all have a requirement for host DNA replication machinery and do not have the ability to cleave their own polypeptides.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Coxsackievirus is known to directly translate viral proteins from the virion's genetic material using host ribosomes and then cleave them into smaller peptides using viral proteases for replication.
